lines.content: This is a project for a greenfield CS2103 Individual Project.
The name Gnosis means knowledge in Greek.
Simply, because my aim in CS2103 (and of course in my other mods) is to expand my knowledge and learning.
The spark to meet your needs.
This project is developed using JDK11.
gnosis.Gnosis provides the ability to create, retrieve and delete different variety of tasks
Different types of tasks includes: todos, deadlines and events.
Creates a todo task without any date/time.
[  ] - denotes a todo that is not marked done.
Creates a deadline task with a specified date/time.
[  ] - denotes a deadline that is not marked done.
Creates an event task with a specified schedule.
[  ] - denotes an event that is not marked done.
Displays all task with task number added.
[  ] - denotes a task that is not marked done.
Listing all tasks in your list:
[X] - denotes a task that is marked has done
Deletes task from task task list.
I hope your needs have been sparked.
Add JUnit tests to test the behavior of the code.
Minimum: More than two test methods, preferably targeting more than one class (if you have multiple classes)
Stretch goal: test methods to target all public methods of all classes
Refer to the JUnit tutorial @se-edu/guides to find how to use JUnit.
-- test whether output is what was intented
-- test whether commands are logically handled
-- specific commands do what they say
Refactor the code to extract out closely related code as classes.
Ui: deals with interactions with the user
Storage: deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file
Parser: deals with making sense of the user command
TaskList: contains the task list e.g., it has operations to add/delete tasks in the list
what I need to achieve for increment:
-- Handles logic between UI and model flow
-- aka logic controller for reciving user command
Implement a skeletal version of Duke that starts by greeting the user, simply echos commands entered by the user, and exits when the user types bye.
What can I do for you?
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
The indentation and horizontal lines are optional.
You are strongly encouraged to customize the chatbot name, command/display formats,
and even the personality of the chatbot to make your chatbot unique.
a. Create a constant variable storing greet message
2. echo commands from user input - DONE
a. can use a switch case following user input
3. exit command upon user input: "bye" - DONE
a. upon "bye" command -> output a exit message (stored in a constant variable)
4. Create a user friendly interface - DONE
a. Can use '\t' and "====" to create simple line blocks
Add the ability to store whatever text entered by the user and display them back to the user when requested.
What can I do for you?
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
There is no need to save the data to the hard disk.
Assume there will be no more than 100 tasks. If you wish, you may use a fixed size array (e.g., String[100]) to store the items.
1. Save text of user input - Done
- Use ArrayList to store texts of user input (String type)
- Iterate through String arraylist of stored text
Add the ability to mark tasks as done.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
When implementing this feature, you are also recommended to implement the following extension:
↳ Use a class to represent tasks
While it is possible to represent a task list as a multi-dimensional array containing primitive values, the more natural approach is to use a model.task class to represent tasks.
-to keep track of String task and a boolean isDone - DONE
- constructor to create task and set isDone false as default - DONE
- use toString() -> to display task -- format: [] (task name) - DONE
2. Ability to mark task by index in list
- Change ArrayList to store model.task instead of String
- Change add command to store task in arraylist
- change behavior of list command for model.task
Add support for tracking three types of tasks:
ToDos: tasks without any date/time attached to it e.g., visit new theme park
Deadlines: tasks that need to be done before a specific date/time e.g., submit report by 11/10/2019 5pm
Events: tasks that start at a specific time and ends at a specific time e.g., team project meeting on 2/10/2019 2-4pm
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 5 tasks in the list.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 6 tasks in the list.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 7 tasks in the list.
At this point, dates/times can be treated as strings; there is no need to convert them to actual dates/times.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 6 tasks in the list.
↳ Use Inheritance to support multiple task types
As there are multiple types of tasks that have some similarity between them, you can implement classes T0do, model.Deadline and model.Event classes to inherit from a model.task class.
Furthermore, use polymorphism to store all tasks in a data structure containing model.task objects e.g., model.task[100].
- need to be done before a specific date/time
Teach Duke to deal with errors such as incorrect inputs entered by the user.
☹ OOPS!!! The description of a todo cannot be empty.
☹ OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(
When implementing this feature, you are also recommended to implement the following extension:
Use exceptions to handle errors. For example, define a class DukeException to represent exceptions specific to Duke.
Minimal: handle at least the two types of errors shown in the example above.
Stretch goal: handle all possible errors in the current version. As you evolve Duke, continue to handle errors related to the new features added.
- task index not found (-1, or more than list size) - Done
- for deadline -> deadline not specified - done
- for event -> schedule not specified - done
Add support for deleting tasks from the list.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
When implementing this feature, you are also recommended to implement the following extension:
Use Java Collections classes for storing data. For example, you can use an ArrayList<model.task> to store the tasks.
- retrieve task to display before removing from list
- add exception for task index out of bounds for delete command

Save the tasks in the hard disk automatically whenever the task list changes. Load the data from the hard disk when Duke starts up. You may hard-code the file name and location e.g., [project_root]/data/duke.txt
The format of the file is up to you. Example:
If you use file paths in your code,
remember to use relative paths rather than absolute paths such as C:\data. If not, your app can cause unpredictable results when used in another computer.
remember to specify file paths in an OS-independent way. If not, your app might not work when used on a different OS.

Your code must handle the case where the data file doesn't exist at the start. Reason: when someone else takes your Duke and runs it for the first time, the required file might not exist in their computer.
Similarly, if you expect the data file to be in as specific folder (e.g., ./data/), you must also handle the folder-does-not-exist-yet case.
Tasks to achieve level-7: (commit to branch-Level-7)
1. Create a task.TaskStorageManager to read/write CSV files - DONE
--> handle case -> where file data doesn't exits -> create default file for them
--> handle case -> folder does not exist -> create folder + file alongside
--> able to read csv file and convert to list of model.task - Done
--> able to write to csv file from list of model.task - Done
--> to include char variable to store type of task
3. Print message of saving and loading to User

Teach Duke how to understand dates and times. For example, if the command is deadline return book /by 2/12/2019 1800, Duke should understand 2/12/2019 1800 as 2nd of December 2019, 6pm, instead of treating it as just a String.
Minimal: Store deadline dates as a java.time.LocalDate in your task objects.
Accept dates in a format such as yyyy-mm-dd format (e.g., 2019-10-15) and print in a different format such as MMM dd yyyy e.g., (Oct 15 2019).
Stretch goal: Use dates and times in more meaningful ways. e.g., add a command to print deadlines/events occurring on a specific date.
What I need to do to achieve level-8:
-- Change deadline/event datetime variables to be of localDateTime  -- Done
-- provide a method to convert String of datetime to a localDateTime type of format : d/MM/yyyy HHmm - DONE
-> ERROR MESSAGE: "ERROR, ENTER DATE FORMAT AS SUCH <day>/<month>/<year> <24HR format time>, e.g: 14/08/2021 1600"
-- provide command for user to search for event/deadline on a specified date: - Coming soon
* gnosis.Gnosis class is the main programme to execute chat-bot assistant.
* Commands gnosis.Gnosis can provide a task tracker to user:
* "done (task number)" - marks specified task as done
* default - adds user input as task
